Description: Mould-made pottery lamp with a voluted rounded-tipped nozzle (now missing), a rounded shoulder and an inward-sloping moulded rim. Between the nozzle volutes is an air-hole. The discus is decorated with two lovers, both entertainers, on a bed: the man reclines on his right elbow on a pillow, and holds his left arm up to the woman who sits away from him, straddling his body. She holds castanets in each hand and wears a breast-band. Sheets are piled on the foot of the bed. The lamp stands on a slightly raised base. Covered with a finger-marked brown slip.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (said to be)
Bibliographic references: Lamp / Catalogue of the Lamps in the British Museum (Q924)
